properties.name: Atlantic City, NJ housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe1301 Bacharach Blvd., Atlantic City, NJ 08401Atlantic City Mayor\'s Office (shown on map, website on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 54,200 median sales price 63.9% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" Full report below. Add places to local map and comments to wiki: https://realestatebubblemap.pbwiki.com/Atlantic%20City%2C%20NJ HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.name: Baltimore Sun: Housing decline hits area unevenly
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe501 N. Calvert St., Baltimore, MD 21278Housing decline hits area unevenly 2/25/07 Pull quote: Sales plummeted more than 20 percent in the county section of her ZIP code last year. For a while, she despaired. She buried not one but two statues of St. Joseph -- the Catholic patron saint of carpenters who is also thought to help with home sales -- in her yard. In the end, Bond lowered her price about 8,000 to 82,000, more than her 00,000 townhouse but not as much as she had expected. FULL TEXT: See link below

properties.name: BankRate:  Selling your house? Bury a saint
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe 11760 US HWY 1, North Palm Beach, FL. 33408http://www.bankrate.com/brm/news/real-estate/20040831a1.asp 8/31/004 Pull quote: Stephen J. Binz believes it works. The author of "St. Joseph, My Real Estate Agent," he became a believer when his own house had been on the market for seven long months. Upon the advice of his Presbyterian real estate agent, Binz buried a St. Joseph statue in his yard. "I thought it was a rather ridiculous superstition," says Binz, a practicing Catholic. But a week later, he had an offer and sold the house. Binz now says it\'s only a superstition if you treat it like one. "The distinction between superstition and devotion is created by the person doing it," says Binz. In other words, if you simply bury St. Joseph and count on that to sell the house, then it\'s superstition. If you do it as an act of faith, then it\'s devotion. FULL TEXT: See link below

properties.name: Bellingham, WA housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe210 Lottie Street, Bellingham, WA 98225Bellingham City Hall (shown on map, website on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 77,000 median sales price 51.5% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.name: Bend, OR housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe710 NW Wall Street, Bend, Oregon 97701Bend City Hall (shown on map, website on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 76,100 median sales price 76.4% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.name: Blog:  Be Sure To Look For The 'Authentic St. Joseph' Label
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe1500 Sansom St., Philadelphia, PA 19102Be Sure To Look For The \'Authentic St. Joseph\' Label 3/19/07 Pull quote: Having trouble selling your home? Why, you definitely need some sort of good-luck charm or witchcraft, like a rabbit\'s foot or a spell that turns prospective buyers who decline to bid into a newt. Or you can go for that time-tested superstitious charm, the St. Joseph statue. FULL TEXT: See link below

properties.name: Blog:  Feast of St. Joe:  Underground Realtor?
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe1717 Ritchie Rd, Forestville, MD 20747Feast of St. Joe: Underground Realtor? Pull quote: Today is the Feast of St. Joseph, Husband of Mary. There is a racket in St. Joseph’s statues where people bury them to sell houses. Using blessed statues and making a prayer for assistance might be an example of Catholic faith. However, could it not be easily corrupted for purposes of GREED? When does a practice of FAITH become SUPERSTITION?

properties.name: Blog:  Inman News and St. Joseph
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe3002 134th Avenue NE, Bellevue, WA 98005Inman News and St. Joseph 8/22/06 Blogger: Ardell DellaLoggiahttp://www.raincityguide.com/author/ARDELL Pull quote: We haven’t heard about this custom for quite awhile because it has been a seller’s market. But based on Inman News giving the custom some attention recently, it looks like St. Joseph may be making a comeback. To Bill Wendel at The Real Estate Cafe, try not to think of all of the agents buying 100 statues at a time and using it as a “gimmick”. Think of my lovely story, and how St. Joseph, while standing on his head, brought some comfort to some very nice people in need of his gentle touch.br>TEXT: See link below, includes extensive comments

properties.name: Blog:  Praying for a Home Sale in New England...
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe8 Hurlbutt Drive , Gales Ferry, CT, 06335Praying for a Home Sale in New England... 11/29/06 Blogger: Author: Linda Davis http://activerain.com/lindadavis As a catholic, I can understand the connection between St. Joseph and praying for a home sale. St. Joseph is the patron saint of homes. I can\'t figure out why he needs to be buried upside down but I suspect he does have a sense of humor. I don\'t consider it blasphemous or superstitious; I actually do believe it works. 2 million or so St. Joseph statues sell each year and I gather many of them end up buried. Right after I wrote my first blog on the subject, one of my home sellers gave it a try and their home sold a week later....to a minister. I really don\'t make these things up. FULL TEXT: See link below

properties.name: Blog:  St. Joseph ~ The Patron Saint of Real Estate
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe16 Kennedy Rd South, Brampton, Ontario L6W 3E1St. Joseph ~ The Patron Saint of Real Estate 3/19/07 Blogger: Brian Madigan http://www2.blogger.com/profile/11691797058615876338 Pull quote: The practice of burying a plastic St. Joseph to help speed the sale of a home dates at least to 1984 in the U.S.A. In 1990 it seemingly became all the rage, with realtors buying plastic saints\' statues by the gross. The standard practice calls for the statue to be dug up once the property has sold and placed on the grateful seller\'s mantle or in another place of honor. Some, however, who have trouble remembering where they interred their statues prefer to leave the buried saints where they\'ve been placed to help protect the properties for the new owners. (Which may not work all that well — some believe leaving the statue underground will cause the land to continue changing hands.) FULL TEXT: See link below

properties.name: Blog:  st. Joseph Isn’t Licensed to Sell Homes
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe17767 Santiago Blvd. Villa Park, CA 92861St. Joseph Isn\'t Licensed to Sell Homes 11/30/07 Blogger: Justin Smithhttp://www.hismove.com/about_us.htm Pull quote: Last November, we were approached by Broderick Perkins, who was at the time doing a story on the Joseph statue phenomenon. I guess he thought that we would have some insight being that we are a Christian company… but I think he was surprised when we told him that we thought the whole thing was ridiculous.br> Although controversial, Joseph was not a real estate agent, and burying his likeness in the ground will NOT help your home sell. Don’t get me wrong, I’m not against praying(to God) for your home to sell… but trusting in a statue to help you sell?? I’ll just use an “above ground” real estate agent, thank you.

properties.name: Boston Globe:  When sales fall, they call St. Joe
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe135 Morrissey Blvd, Boston, MA 02125When sales fall, they call St. Joe 8/20/06 Pull quotes: The tradition of burying St. Joseph statues started about 500 years ago in Europe, according to Cates. An order of nuns, needing more land for a convent, buried their St. Joseph medals in the ground. They got the land, and word spread. The medals eventually turned into statues, and Joseph, a carpenter, who with Jesus and Mary makes up the Holy Family, became the unofficial saint of real estate. The church takes no formal position on the statues — "It is not official church practice," said Terrence Donilon, spokesman for the Archdiocese of Boston. "It is more of a personal tradition for some people."br> But Angele Fillion, a clerk at the St. Joseph the Worker Shrine, calls the practice akin to voodoo.br> "It’s not the statue, it’s the faith that makes it work," said Fillion, who said she frequently has to restrain herself from coming on too strong about the importance of prayer to troubled homeowners who enter the shop looking for the statues — and little else. FULL TEXT: See link below

properties.name: Boston:  167 Commonwealth Ave, Unit 3
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe167 Commonwealth Ave, Unit 3, Boston, MAOur first example of how the nationwide credit crunch is hitting Boston, MA. Originally listed at 95,000 on 3/22/07, this MLS property has been under agreement three times over the past five months: 1. Underagreement on 5/22 and back on the market on 5/23/07; 2. properties.name: Bridgeport, CT price correction
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe999 Broad St, Bridgeport, CT 06604Bridgeport City Hall (shown on map and on link above) PAST HOUSING PRICE CORRECTION Price decline: 16% Duration: 3.25 years (13 quarters) Period: 1988Q1-1991Q1 Overvaluation prior to price correction: 59% Valuation peak: 1987Q1 CURRENT VALUATION: 2006Q1 See report below, and add data to this map or your own Source: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm ========== If you owned property in Bridgeport (or another city) during this price correction or another downcycle, please post comments below. Better yet, ADD the location of your former property to this map and tell your story so others can learn from your experience. Here\'s a podcast of lessons learned from riding two real estate cycles: http://tinyurl.com/s8nmx Our goal is to protect potential homebuyers, particularly those contemplating risky loans in overvalued housing markets, from making costly mistakes. If you were harmed by a previous real estate price correction: (1) what advice would you give to someone buying a home now, and (2) what should they know about the current housing market? If price corrections are already underway locally, post your comments or locations of properties on this map: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7060 If you are househunting outside Massachusetts, The Real Estate Cafe would be glad to refer you to an exclusive buyer agent -- perhaps one contributing to this map -- and rebate one-third of our referral fee (where allowed by law). We\'ll donate the other third to help save lives or provide shelter subsidies for AIDS orphans. Did you know there are more than 15 million AIDS orphans worldwide? http://tinyurl.com/kl5nc If you are not in the housing market yourself, you can help friends save money AND save lives by emailing this link to anyone buying (or selling) a home. Alternatively, ask them to visit http://www.realestatecafe.blogs.com, email RECafe@mac.com, or call us at 617-661-4046.

properties.name: Cambridge, MA price correction
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe795 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge, MA 02139Cambridge City Hall (shown on map, website on link above) PAST HOUSING PRICE CORRECTION Price decline: 12% Duration: 2 years (8 quarters) Period: 1989Q4-1991Q3 Overvaluation prior to price correction: 40% Valuation peak: 1987Q1 CURRENT VALUATION: 2006Q1 91,400 median sales price 3.5% overvalued Not among the 71 "Extremely overvalued" housing markets nationwide Still, single family homes are selling for below assessed value, see: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/6343 Source: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm ========== If you owned property in Cambridge during this price correction, or another downcycle, please post comments below. Better yet, ADD the location of your former property to this map and tell your story so others can learn from your experience. Our goal is to protect potential homebuyers, particularly those contemplating risky loans in overvalued housing markets, from making costly mistakes. If you were harmed by a previous real estate price correction: (1) what advice would you give to someone buying a home now, and (2) what should they know about the current housing market? If price corrections are already underway locally, post your comments or locations of properties on this map: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/6343 If you are househunting outside Massachusetts, The Real Estate Cafe would be glad to refer you to an exclusive buyer agent -- perhaps one contributing to this map -- and rebate one-third of our referral fee (where allowed by law). We\'ll donate the other third to help save lives or provide shelter subsidies for AIDS orphans. Did you know there are more than 15 million AIDS orphans worldwide? http://tinyurl.com/kl5nc If you are not in the housing market yourself, you can help friends save money AND save lives by emailing this link to anyone buying (or selling) a home. Alternatively, ask them to visit http://www.realestatecafe.blogs.com, email RECafe@mac.com, or call us at 617-661-4046.

properties.name: Carson City, NV housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe201 North Carson St., Carson City, NV 89701Carson City Hall (shown on map, website on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 91,300 median sales price 45.6% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.name: Contra Costa Times: Pope not winning popularity contest
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe2640 Shadelands Dr, Walnut Creek, CA 94598Pope not winning popularity contest 3/17/07 Pull quote: It was a typical weekday afternoon at the Long Island Catholic Supply store in Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City, N.Y. A few teenagers stopped in to get bracelets reading "WWJD?" - or "What Would Jesus Do?" - and adults hoping to sell their houses purchased miniature statues of St. Joseph, the patron saint of real estate. What the customers weren\'t buying stood out. No one stopped for a Pope Benedict XVI plaque or a Pope Benedict book, or by the cash register for a Pope Benedict commemorative coin. FULL TEXT: See link below

properties.name: Corpus Christi, TX price correction
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe1201 Leopard St, Corpus Christi, TX 78401Corpus Christi City Hall (shown on map and on link above) PAST HOUSING PRICE CORRECTION Price decline: 19% Duration: 3 years (12 quarters) Period: 1986Q2-1989Q1 Overvaluation prior to price correction: 43% Valuation peak: 1986Q2 CURRENT VALUATION: 2006Q1 See report below, and add data to this map or your own Source: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm ========== If you owned property in Corpus Christi (or another city) during this price correction or another downcycle, please post comments below. Better yet, ADD the location of your former property to this map and tell your story so others can learn from your experience. Here\'s a podcast of lessons learned from riding two real estate cycles: http://tinyurl.com/s8nmx Our goal is to protect potential homebuyers, particularly those contemplating risky loans in overvalued housing markets, from making costly mistakes. If you were harmed by a previous real estate price correction: (1) what advice would you give to someone buying a home now, and (2) what should they know about the current housing market? If price corrections are already underway locally, post your comments or locations of properties on this map: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7060 If you are househunting outside Massachusetts, The Real Estate Cafe would be glad to refer you to an exclusive buyer agent -- perhaps one contributing to this map -- and rebate one-third of our referral fee (where allowed by law). We\'ll donate the other third to help save lives or provide shelter subsidies for AIDS orphans. Did you know there are more than 15 million AIDS orphans worldwide? http://tinyurl.com/kl5nc If you are not in the housing market yourself, you can help friends save money AND save lives by emailing this link to anyone buying (or selling) a home. Alternatively, ask them to visit http://www.realestatecafe.blogs.com, email RECafe@mac.com, or call us at 617-661-4046.

properties.name: Courier Post: Holy intervention in home sales
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe301 Cuthbert Blvd, Cherry Hill, NJ 08002Holy intervention in home sales 3/19/07 Pull quotes: "When things get bad, people get religious," said Daniel Castonguay, who runs Abbott Church Goods on Route 38 in Cherry Hill and also operates ourfather.com. "When the real estate market gets soft, people hear about it from friends and Realtors. We\'ve even had Jewish people come in for them and joke that they\'ll convert if it works." Walton said burying St. Joseph statues is not part of church teaching. He said the statue is just a reminder of something spiritual. "The church teaches that saints can make prayerful intercession," Walton said. "The communion of saints can be efficacious. God answers prayers, but it may not be the answer you\'re expecting." FULL TEXT: See link below

properties.name: Dallas, TX price correction
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe1500 Marilla Street, Dallas, TX 75201Dallas City Hall (shown on map, website on link above) PAST HOUSING PRICE CORRECTION Price corrections, as defined by Global Insight (source of this data), are "declines of at least 10 percent over a period of at least 8 quarters." Price decline: 18% Duration: 3 years (12 quarters) Period: 1986Q2-1989Q1 Overvaluation prior to price correction: 58% Valuation peak: 1985Q1 CURRENT VALUATION: 2006Q1 29,000 median sales price 18.9% UNDERvalued Source: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm ========== If you owned property in Dallas during this price correction, or another downcycle, please post comments below. Better yet, ADD the location of your former property to this map and tell your story so others can learn from your experience. Our goal is to protect potential homebuyers, particularly those contemplating risky loans in overvalued housing markets, from making costly mistakes. If you were harmed by a previous real estate price correction: (1) what advice would you give to someone buying a home now, and (2) what should they know about the current housing market? If price corrections are already underway locally, post your comments or locations of properties on this map: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7060 If you are househunting outside Massachusetts, The Real Estate Cafe would be glad to refer you to an exclusive buyer agent -- perhaps one contributing to this map -- and rebate one-third of our referral fee (where allowed by law). We\'ll donate the other third to help save lives or provide shelter subsidies for AIDS orphans. Did you know there are more than 15 million AIDS orphans worldwide? http://tinyurl.com/kl5nc If you are not in the housing market yourself, you can help friends save money AND save lives by emailing this link to anyone buying (or selling) a home. Alternatively, ask them to visit http://www.realestatecafe.blogs.com, email RECafe@mac.com, or call us at 617-661-4046.

properties.name: Fort Lauderdale, FL housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe100 N. Andrews Ave, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33301Fort Lauderdale City Hall (shown on map and on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 62,600 median sales price 57.3% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" How long have previous housing price corrections lasted? How far have prices fallen? See nationwide map at: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7317 HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.name: Hattiesburg, MS price correction
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe200 Forrest St, Hattiesburg, MSHattiesburg City Hall (shown on map and on link above) PAST HOUSING PRICE CORRECTION Price decline: 14% Duration: 2.25 years (9 quarters) Period: 1987Q1-1989Q1 Overvaluation prior to price correction: 38% Valuation peak: 1987Q1 CURRENT VALUATION: 2006Q1 See report below, and add data to this map or your own Source: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm ========== If you owned property in Hattiesburg (or another city) during this price correction or another downcycle, please post comments below. Better yet, ADD the location of your former property to this map and tell your story so others can learn from your experience. Here\'s a podcast of lessons learned from riding two real estate cycles: http://tinyurl.com/s8nmx Our goal is to protect potential homebuyers, particularly those contemplating risky loans in overvalued housing markets, from making costly mistakes. If you were harmed by a previous real estate price correction: (1) what advice would you give to someone buying a home now, and (2) what should they know about the current housing market? If price corrections are already underway locally, post your comments or locations of properties on this map: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7060 If you are househunting outside Massachusetts, The Real Estate Cafe would be glad to refer you to an exclusive buyer agent -- perhaps one contributing to this map -- and rebate one-third of our referral fee (where allowed by law). We\'ll donate the other third to help save lives or provide shelter subsidies for AIDS orphans. Did you know there are more than 15 million AIDS orphans worldwide? http://tinyurl.com/kl5nc If you are not in the housing market yourself, you can help friends save money AND save lives by emailing this link to anyone buying (or selling) a home. Alternatively, ask them to visit http://www.realestatecafe.blogs.com, email RECafe@mac.com, or call us at 617-661-4046.

properties.name: Honolulu, HI price correction
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe530 South King St, Honolulu, HI 96813City & County of Honolulu (shown on map and on link above) PAST HOUSING PRICE CORRECTION Price decline: 20% Duration: 5 years (20 quarters) Period: 1994Q4-1999Q3 Overvaluation prior to price correction: 20% Valuation peak: 1991Q2 CURRENT VALUATION: 2006Q1 See report below, and add data to this map or your own Source: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm ========== If you owned property in Honolulu (or another city) during this price correction or another downcycle, please post comments below. Better yet, ADD the location of your former property to this map and tell your story so others can learn from your experience. Here\'s a podcast of lessons learned from riding two real estate cycles: http://tinyurl.com/s8nmx Our goal is to protect potential homebuyers, particularly those contemplating risky loans in overvalued housing markets, from making costly mistakes. If you were harmed by a previous real estate price correction: (1) what advice would you give to someone buying a home now, and (2) what should they know about the current housing market? If price corrections are already underway locally, post your comments or locations of properties on this map: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7060 If you are househunting outside Massachusetts, The Real Estate Cafe would be glad to refer you to an exclusive buyer agent -- perhaps one contributing to this map -- and rebate one-third of our referral fee (where allowed by law). We\'ll donate the other third to help save lives or provide shelter subsidies for AIDS orphans. Did you know there are more than 15 million AIDS orphans worldwide? http://tinyurl.com/kl5nc If you are not in the housing market yourself, you can help friends save money AND save lives by emailing this link to anyone buying (or selling) a home. Alternatively, ask them to visit http://www.realestatecafe.blogs.com, email RECafe@mac.com, or call us at 617-661-4046.

properties.name: Kingston, NY housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe420 Broadway, Kingston, NY 12401Kingston City Hall (shown on map, website on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 20,500 median sales price 45.7% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.name: Los Angeles, CA housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe 200 N. Spring St., Los Angeles, CA 90012Los Angeles City Hall (shown on map and link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 99,300 median sales price 61.3% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" Full report below. Add places to local map and comments to wiki: http://realestatebubblemap.pbwiki.com/Los%20Angeles%2C%20CA How long did the last housing price correction last? How far did prices fall? See: http://platial.com/place/95116 HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.name: Medford, OR housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe411 West 8th St, Medford, Oregon 97501Medford City Hall (shown on map and on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 76,000 median sales price 66.4% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" How long have previous housing price corrections lasted? How far have prices fallen? See nationwide map at: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7317 HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe432 Tuxedo Blvd, Webster Groves, MO 63105The Wendel\'s moved from University City to Webster Groves in approximately 1959 just before Paul Wendel, now 47 was born.

properties.name: Mom's current home (aka. Hotel Wendel)
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe 90 Arundel Pl, Clayton, MO 63105Mom (then 38 years old) and Dad (42 years old) moved here in approximately 1970, and bought this extraordinary 10 room, three story, English tudor-styel home for approximately 5,000. The family of six moved during the summer, when Bill was entering sophomore year at St. Louis University High School, George was entering his junior year, Peter was entering 8th grade, and Paul was entering 6th grade. Over the past 37 years, Hotel Wendel has also provided short-term housing for cousins and the next generation of Wendel\'s: Valerie Collins Pope lived here during the summer of 197? while attending nursing school at St. Louis University Carolyn Wendel lived here during the summer of 200? while studying pre-med at St. Louis University Meghan K... lived here during the summer of 200? while finishing her nursing program at St. Louis University

properties.name: Newark, NJ housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe920 Broad Street Newark, NJ 07102Newark City Hall (shown on map and on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 81,900 median sales price 27.2% overvalued Overvalued but NOT one of 71 "extremely overvalued" housing markets How long did the last housing price correction last? How far did prices fall? See: http://www.platial.com/place/95509 HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.name: Norwich, CT price correction
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe100 Broadway, Norwich, CT 06360Norwich City Hall (shown on map and on link above) PAST HOUSING PRICE CORRECTION Price decline: 16% Duration: 3.5 years (14 quarters) Period: 1988Q4-1992Q2 Overvaluation prior to price correction: 39% Valuation peak: 1988Q1 CURRENT VALUATION: 2006Q1 See report below, and add data to this map or your own Source: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm ========== If you owned property in Norwich (or another city) during this price correction or another downcycle, please post comments below. Better yet, ADD the location of your former property to this map and tell your story so others can learn from your experience. Here\'s a podcast of lessons learned from riding two real estate cycles: http://tinyurl.com/s8nmx Our goal is to protect potential homebuyers, particularly those contemplating risky loans in overvalued housing markets, from making costly mistakes. If you were harmed by a previous real estate price correction: (1) what advice would you give to someone buying a home now, and (2) what should they know about the current housing market? If price corrections are already underway locally, post your comments or locations of properties on this map: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7060 If you are househunting outside Massachusetts, The Real Estate Cafe would be glad to refer you to an exclusive buyer agent -- perhaps one contributing to this map -- and rebate one-third of our referral fee (where allowed by law). We\'ll donate the other third to help save lives or provide shelter subsidies for AIDS orphans. Did you know there are more than 15 million AIDS orphans worldwide? http://tinyurl.com/kl5nc If you are not in the housing market yourself, you can help friends save money AND save lives by emailing this link to anyone buying (or selling) a home. Alternatively, ask them to visit http://www.realestatecafe.blogs.com, email RECafe@mac.com, or call us at 617-661-4046.

properties.name: Ocean City, NJ housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe861 Asbury Avenue, Ocean City, NJ 08226 Ocean City Hall (shown on map and on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 10,100 median sales price 54.6% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." properties.name: Providence Journal: Making the sale
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe75 Fountain St., Providence, RI 02902Making the sale 3/11/07 Pull quote: The Rev. Michael Najim, assistant vocation director for the Diocese of Providence, says burying a statue of St. Joseph hoping to sell a house “borders on superstition,” which the church does not support. But he says the prayer that’s supposed to be used with the statue recognizes “a deeper reality: People believe in the power of prayer. And people asking St. Joseph, the protector and provider of the Holy Family, to intercede for them is a wonderful Catholic practice.” FULL TEXT: See link below

VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 72,200 median sales price 53.6% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" How long did the last housing price correction last? How far did prices fall? See: http://www.platial.com/place/95503 HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.name: Sarasota, FL housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe1565 First St, Sarasota, FL 34236Sarasota City Hall (shown on map and on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 49,000 median sales price 64.4% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" How long have previous housing price corrections lasted? How far have prices fallen? See nationwide map at: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7317 HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.name: TV:  Calling for a miracle to sell your home
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe Cleveland, OH 44114Pull quote: "The amount of success stories is just amazing. People have sold it in a few days. They have gotten their asking price. They have had more than one offer. He is extremely popular. We sell on average say 3 to 10 a day. We even have real estate agents come in and buy him", says Vickie Gannon of Gannon\'s Gift Store on Lorain Avenue in Fairview Park. The store sells home selling kits for as low as .99. Commentary: Coverage says, "According to some, there is a right way to bury St. Joseph. Most believe he should be planted upside down and facing the street. " but doesn\'t say that some Catholics and others believe the practice to be misguided. For more backround information on St. Joseph, read: Beyond Superstition: Doing Justice to the "Just Man" http://realestatecafe.pbwiki.com/Doing+Justice+to+St+Joseph

properties.name: Times-Picayune: St. Joseph, help me sell the house
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe 400 Poydras St. New Orleans, LA 70130St. Joseph, help me sell the house 8/20/97 Pull quote: Thomas Farrell, 40, the owner of Our Daily Bread, a Catholic supply store in Sayville, N.Y., says he frowns on the practice because he thinks it has crossed into the realm of mysticism and superstition. Farrell says he often counsels shoppers to simply recite a short, heartfelt prayer requesting St. Joseph\'s intercession to sell their homes. FULL TEXT: See link below

properties.name: Vallejo, CA housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe555 Santa Clara St, Vallejo, CA 94590Vallejo City Hall (shown on map and on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 07,600 median sales price 57.0% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" How long have previous housing price corrections lasted? How far have prices fallen? See nationwide map at: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7317 HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued,Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

properties.name: Website:  Should you bury a statue of St. Joseph to help sell your house?
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe11 East Illinois Street, Chicago, IL 60611Should you bury a statue of St. Joseph to help sell your house? 3/20/00 Pull quote: Does doing all this guarantee that St. Joseph will sell your house? Of course not. It\'s a silly superstition. But 2 million St. Joseph statues are sold nationally each year with enough testimonials from satistified home sellers to make believers out of many. I\'ll confess that as I write this, I\'m staring out my window at the lovely new statue of St. Joseph and his family we placed in our back yard. When I buried him at our old home (which I sold myself), we had our buyer within a week. FULL TEXT: See link below

properties.name: West Palm Beach, FL housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe  200 2nd St, West Palm Beach, FL 33401West Palm Beach City Hall (shown on map and on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 87,700 median sales price 65.5% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" How long have previous housing price corrections lasted? How far have prices fallen? See nationwide map at: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7317 HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm

Better yet, ADD the location of your former property to this map and tell your story so others can learn from your experience. properties.name: Yuba City, CA housing market
properties.description: Posted by Realestatecafe1201 Civic Center Blvd, Yuba City, CAYuba Civic Center (shown on map and on link above) GLOBAL INSIGHT / NATIONAL CITY CORP. VALUATION: 2006/Q1 (see link to full report below) 69,100 median sales price 67.9% overvalued Classification: "Extremely overvalued" How long have previous housing price corrections lasted? How far have prices fallen? See nationwide map at: http://www.platial.com/realestatecafe/map/7317 HOUSING BUBBLE CORRECTION COULD BE SEVERE U.S. News & World Report (6/13/06) EXCERPTS "In the first quarter [of 2006], home prices nationwide rose an additional 7.3 percent, according to a joint study by the financial services firm National City Corp. and the research firm Global Insight. As a result, there are now 71 metropolitan areas–representing nearly 40 percent of all single-family homes–that can be classified as "extremely overvalued," according to the study. By comparison, only 64 metro regions were considered frothy at the end of last year and only 1 percent were classified as such in the first quarter of 2004." "The fact that this number of metro areas – representing such a large percent of the total single family market–is extremely overvalued should be a cause for concern," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist for National City. The bottom line: Real estate prices eventually correct themselves. And unfortunately for homeowners, it often takes years before home prices start to rise again, especially after a big run up. National City recently studied 66 major metro regions over the past 21 years that suffered through a 10 percent or greater decline in prices for at least a two-year period of time. It found that home prices, once they begin to correct, tend to decline 17 percent on average before markets heal themselves. "And the average duration of these adjustments is 3.5 years," says DeKaser. FULL TEXT: http://tinyurl.com/gdozq DEFINITION: Valuations in excess of 34% are classified as "extremely overvalued." A complete ranking of overvalued and undervalued housing markets, as well as past price declines and duration of market corrections are available in PDF form from the link below: FULL REPORT: Overvalued Housing Market? Depends Where You Live Most Overvalued, Most Undervalued of the 317 Largest U.S. Metro Areas Examined http://www.globalinsight.com/Highlight/HighlightDetail2350.htm
